channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Here are 10 science-backed tips to help you get healthier
item.description: New routines don’t stick overnight, our Ask a Doctor columnist Dr. Trisha Pasricha writes. So pick one habit at a time and make it as easy as possible.

item.title: Justice Department sues D.C. over ban of AR-15s and other semiautomatic guns
item.description: Government attorneys chastised the city for its code that bans most semiautomatic rifles and certain firearms from being registered with the police department, ultimately making any possession of those weapons illegal.

item.title: ‘60 Minutes’ executive producer told staff she stands by segment but ‘had to comply’ when CBS News chief Bari Weiss shelved it
item.description: The postponed segment was set to cover the Trump administration’s deportations of Venezuelan migrants to El Salvador’s CECOT prison. Weiss this weekend said the story could not run after the administration refused to grant an interview, according to an internal email. “We pushed back, we defended our story, but she wanted changes, and I ultimately had to comply,” EP Tanya Simon said to staff, according to a partial transcript of the meeting.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Second-guessing choices after putting down a beloved dog
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Second-guessing choices after putting down a beloved dog

item.title: The best state of the year? Here is the winner of the Editorial Board’s new year-end tradition.
item.description: Which of the 50 improved the most in 2025?

item.title: Your holiday-themed week of On the Record starts today
item.description: Answer now to earn your festive Monday points.

item.title: They survived a Cybertruck crash. Then a fire killed them.
item.description: In several instances, Tesla passengers have struggled to access or exit the vehicles during life-threatening emergencies, including fires. Lawsuits allege the company’s futuristic features have caused injuries and deaths.

item.title: Ted Cruz. Epstein files. Federal worker stories. Venezuela. Remote work. Holiday travel forecast. Video games. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: A middle-class family’s only option: A $43,000 health insurance premium
item.description: Consumers are left with few options and crushing prices as insurers offering Affordable Care Act plans pull out of some regions.

item.title: 23 Christmas traditions, ranked from worst to best
item.description: We love them, we hate them, we complain and then do them anyway. Based on an entirely unscientific and highly emotional survey of Washington Post staffers, we explain which experiences makes us crazy and the ones we can’t live without.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.

item.title: The year Trump broke the federal government
item.description: Millions of federal employees were caught up in a once-unthinkable overhaul of the nation’s sprawling bureaucracy, carried out in less than a year by one of the most polarizing presidents in American history. And more changes are coming.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: The ‘TrumpKennedyCenter.org’ website is taken. This comedian owns it.
item.description: The creator of satirical websites bought the domain this summer and is plotting its content, even if some things are “hard to parody.”

item.title: Inside the 17-year lawsuit between a Trump official and his interior designers
item.description: Pete Marocco helped dismantle USAID in weeks. But for nearly two decades, he has been embroiled in a legal “boondoggle” in Tallahassee.

item.title: Saving pedestrian lives is not that hard. Here’s what one city is doing.
item.description: As the rate of pedestrian deaths soars, The Washington Post priced out practical solutions and examined what Albuquerque has pursued to show what is possible.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Tucker Carlson inflames a raging battle for MAGA’s future
item.description: The provocative podcaster has an audience – online, among influencers and inside the White House. That worries some on the right.

item.title: Trump renaming calls the Kennedy Center’s legacy into question
item.description: Can he do that? Is it legal? Most of us haven’t experienced this level of dissonant brand synergy since our first visit to a combination KFC/Taco Bell, writes Michael Andor Brodeur.

item.title: U.S. strikes dozens of sites in Syria in retaliation for killing of two American soldiers and an interpreter
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth acknowledged the strikes, saying U.S. forces had begun Operation Hawkeye Strike “in direct response to the attack” on American personnel last weekend in Palmyra. “This is not the beginning of the war — it is a declaration of vengeance,” Hegseth said.

item.title: U.S. plans to stop recommending most vaccines for children and defer to doctors
item.description: This approach, which is not finalized, would mark a fundamental shift in the health care system that generally relies on federal health agencies to guide how children are protected against disease. It was not immediately clear which shots would no longer be recommended.

item.title: Republican Rep. Elise Stefanik ends her bid for New York governor and won’t run again for House
item.description: The surprising move comes just weeks after Stefanik officially entered the race to unseat Democratic Gov. Kathy Hochul. The state’s Republican primary became complicated earlier this month when Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman — a longtime New York ally of President Donald Trump — jumped into the race.

item.title: Justice Department releases huge trove of Jeffrey Epstein documents
item.description: The release comes in response to federal legislation that ordered officials to make public a collection of records that has long been sought by his victims but was entangled in political controversy.

item.title: The slain MIT professor’s career was flourishing. His suspected killer’s foundered after a stint at Brown University.
item.description: Nuno Loureiro and Claudio Neves Valente were once peers — brilliant aspiring scientists working toward a degree at Portugal’s most prestigious engineering school. On Monday, Valente hunted down Loureiro, shooting and killing him at his home near Boston, authorities said. It was the second act in a deadly rampage that began at Brown University 48 hours earlier.

item.title: University of Virginia names Scott Beardsley its new president despite calls from Spanberger and others for a delay
item.description: U-Va. named the longtime dean of its business school as the next president of the state’s flagship university, despite calls from Gov.-elect Abigail Spanberger (D) to pause the search for the top post until she takes office next month.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: My husband wants me to pretend his parents like me
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: My husband wants me to pretend his parents like me

item.title: Kennedy Center adds Donald Trump’s name to building exterior
item.description: A blue tarp was stretched across a portion of the building as a small team on scaffolding started the work. The signage change follows a vote by the board of trustees to rename the performing arts complex “the Trump Kennedy Center.”

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Brown University gunman. Kennedy Center. Fraud victims. Swastika policy. Putin call-in. How to feel awe. Polar bear. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Judge in Wisconsin convicted of helping immigrant avoid arrest by ICE
item.description: The jury found Milwaukee County Judge Hannah Dugan guilty of a felony, obstructing an official proceeding, but acquitted her of a misdemeanor, concealing a person from arrest. She could be sentenced to up to five years in prison.

item.title: Brown University shooting suspect found dead in New Hampshire storage facility, authorities announce
item.description: The announcement ends a five-day manhunt that appeared to stump investigators and kept the university and surrounding communities on edge.

item.title: University of Virginia likely to appoint new president Friday despite call from governor-elect to halt search, people familiar say
item.description: A search committee has spent months considering candidates. But a vote Friday could spark backlash on and off campus after calls in recent weeks by Gov.-elect Abigail Spanberger (D) and others for the board to pause the process until she takes office in January.

item.title: Coast Guard abruptly deletes swastika, noose entry from policy manual after blowback to labeling them as only ‘potentially divisive’
item.description: The announcement caps a tumultuous few weeks within the Coast Guard, following Washington Post reports detailing the service’s plan to include the incendiary language within its new workplace harassment manual, its vow to reverse course in the face of widespread criticism, and the wording’s surprising retention as the new manual took effect earlier this week.

item.title: Lower crime, but deeper distrust: How the Trump crackdown rattled one community
item.description: President Donald Trump took over D.C. police for 30 days this summer. Despite a dip in violent crime, residents of 10th Place in Southeast Washington said the tactics used by law enforcement deepened their distrust of authorities and made them feel no safer.

item.title: Kennedy Center board votes to rename the institution as the Trump-Kennedy Center. It’s unclear whether the change is legal.
item.description: The apparent change comes after months of President Donald Trump repeatedly joking about the move, including at the Kennedy Center Honors. It follows a year of upheaval at the center, after Trump overhauled it in February. Officials did not immediately cite an authority for the board’s ability to change the institution’s name.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Is it fair of anti-holiday spouse to ruin the season for the other?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Is it fair of anti-holiday spouse to ruin the season for the other?

item.title: Trump administration to revoke funding from hospitals that offer youth gender transition care
item.description: The administration has planned to eject medical providers from major federal health insurance programs if they provide services including hormone therapy, puberty blockers or procedures such as mastectomies to children and teenagers. The rules, if finalized, could result in a wide-scale contraction of the availability of transition services for children.

item.title: Democrats will not release autopsy of 2024 loss, aiming to avoid contentious fights over party’s failing
item.description: Operatives involved in drafting the autopsy worried that revisiting Kamala Harris’s loss to Donald Trump would reignite the fiery internal debates that consumed the party at a time when Democrats are eager to celebrate a string of wins in 2025 and focus on the 2026 midterms, officials said.

item.title: Trump adviser Stephen Miller’s hard-line Mexico strategy morphed into deadly boat strikes near Venezuela
item.description: Miller has been a driving force behind the Trump administration’s counternarcotics campaign, pressing for results and fresh military options that could be turned into future operations, current and former officials said.

item.title: There will be no postseason for Chiefs kingdom in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Inflation cooled unexpectedly in November, giving consumers a bit of relief in a surprising turn for the economy
item.description: The November consumer price index reported prices rose at a 2.7 percent rate from a year earlier, cooler than the most-recent reading from September, according to new data from the Labor Department on Thursday.

item.title: Trump address. White House plaques. Swastika policy. Leftist networks. Health cuts. Satellites. Alzheimer’s test. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Government admits failures by Army and air traffic controllers in DCA crash
item.description: In a court filing, the government says “collective failures caused the mid-air collision that resulted in the senseless and tragic deaths of 67 individuals.”

item.title: What started as a 31-day stay became a ‘nightmare’ for a D.C. Airbnb host
item.description: A D.C. property owner said a woman stopped paying rent and claimed tenant rights to keep from being evicted.

item.title: Washington Nationals to hire 31-year-old Anirudh Kilambi as general manager
item.description: New president of baseball operations Paul Toboni is hiring Kilambi as his second-in-command in the organization’s front office. Kilambi arrives from the Philadelphia Phillies, where he spent four years as an assistant general manager overseeing their analytics department.

item.title: After Bondi Beach, it's a Hanukkah without light
item.description: For the crime of being Jewish, my people die and fight alone

item.title: FBI Deputy Director Dan Bongino announces he will step down next month
item.description: Bongino left a lucrative job as a conservative podcaster to serve as second-in-command at the FBI when Donald Trump became president. “Dan did a great job,” the president told reporters Wednesday. “I think he wants to go back to his show.”

item.title: I spoke to America’s ‘weirdest Democrat.’ And he’s on to something.
item.description: There’s no one in politics quite like the Democratic governor of Colorado, Jared Polis.

item.title: Senators freeze Coast Guard admiral’s promotion after the service enacted a new swastika and noose policy
item.description: The Democratic senators’ action follows a Washington Post report revealing that, despite Adm. Kevin Lunday’s forceful denunciation of such symbols and a separate directive he issued prohibiting them, the service allowed a policy to take effect that downgrades their definition from hate symbols to “potentially divisive.”

item.title: The Oscars will air on YouTube starting in 2029, departing ABC after more than half a century
item.description: ABC will continue to broadcast the Oscars through 2028, but YouTube has the global rights to air the awards ceremony until 2033. The awards show will be aired for free.
